Chapter 19: Rules for Receiving the Precepts The rules for going forth in the Western Regions are all fully established by the sages, as extensively explained in the Hundred and One Karman Procedures. Here, I will only briefly point out the directions.

Having put on the Dharma robes, he is given the bowl and implements. This is called going forth.

As for the five periods, since the customs of different regions are different and the number of months is combined or separated, if it is not pointed out, it is difficult to know in detail.

20. Bathing at Appropriate Times Bathing at Appropriate Times As for the method of bathing, the Western Regions is different from Eastern Xia. But the climate is harmonious and slightly different from other places.
In the twelve months, flowers and fruits are always present. They do not know ice and snow, but there is slight frost. Although it is often hot, it is not unbearably hot.
When it is hot, the body does not need a fan, and when it is cold, the feet do not crack. Because many people bathe here, their bodies are still clean. They do not eat without bathing every day.
Moreover, wherever they are, there is plenty of pond water. People often dig ponds as a blessing.
If they travel one post station, they will see thirty or forty ponds, some as wide as one mu or five mu.
On the four sides, they plant tÄla trees, forty to fifty feet tall.
The ponds all collect rainwater, as clear as a flowing river.
At the eight stÅ«pas, there are bathing ponds of the World-Honored One. The water is clear and delicious, different from the others.

There are more than ten large ponds in NÄlandÄ Monastery. Every morning, the monastery strikes a gong to let the monks bathe. Everyone brings their own bathing skirt, either a thousand or a hundred, and goes out of the monastery together, scattering to the various ponds to bathe.

The method of the bathing skirt is to use a cloth five cubits long and half a cubit wide, wrap it around the body to make a turn, pull out the old skirt, turn the two ends to the front, take the left corner, pull it towards the waist with the right hand to make it close to the body, and press the right side into the waist.
This is called the method of wearing a bathing skirt.
The method of wearing a skirt when lying down is also the same.
When wanting to come out of the pond, shake it out and come out slowly, do not let insects attach to it.
The method of going up the bank is explained in detail in the Vinaya.
If one does not go to the pond, but washes in the monastery, wearing a skirt is the same as this. The water is sprinkled by a person, and a barrier can be set up according to the place and time.

The World-Honored One taught to build a bathhouse, either an open-air brick pool or a medicinal bath to cure illnesses, or to apply oil all over the body, to always oil the feet at night, and to apply oil on the head every morning. These are beneficial for brightening the eyes and dispelling wind, and all have the holy teachings, but I will not elaborate in detail as it is extensively explained in the Vinaya.
Moreover, all those who take a bath should do so when hungry.
After bathing, one may then eat, as there are two benefits:
First, the body is pure and free from impurities; second, phlegm and tumors are dispersed, and one can eat food.
Bathing after a full meal is prohibited by medical experts.
Therefore, we know that the saying bathe when hungry, bathe when full is not a universal principle.
If one wears a three-foot bathing robe, it is narrow and exposes the body;
Or if one does not wear anything at all and bathes naked, it greatly violates the teachings and principles.
One should use a four-panel washing skirt to cover the body, which is lovely. Not only does it respectfully follow the holy teachings, but it also does not shame the spirits.
The rest of the practices that are not necessary, the wise ones should know.
Even when bathing at night, one does not change one's appearance, so how could one cover oneself when facing people?
Wearing the sitting mat on the body, twenty-one wearing the sitting mat on the body to pay respects, spreading out the sitting mat, is not seen in the Five Indias.

The monks in the South Seas each carry a cloth towel three to five feet long, folded like a dining towel, used to cover the knees when paying respects, and worn over the shoulder when walking.
